title: 104_s1857
content: The "Bipartisan Campaign Practices Commission Act of 1996" establishes the Bipartisan Commission on Campaign Practices to fulfill specific duties. The Bipartisan Commission on Campaign Practices, established by the "Bipartisan Campaign Practices Commission Act of 1996," is tasked with studying laws and regulations affecting Federal campaign practices. It considers the amount of money spent on campaigns, the qualifications of candidates, the promotion of trust in the political process, and media access for the electorate. The Bipartisan Commission on Campaign Practices, established by the "Bipartisan Campaign Practices Commission Act of 1996," studies laws and regulations affecting Federal campaign practices. It considers the qualifications of candidates, campaign financing, promoting trust in the political process, media access for the electorate, and other relevant matters. SEC. 4. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission consists of 9 private sector members appointed by various leaders, with a chairperson selected by majority vote within 7 days of all appointments. The chairperson of the Commission is appointed by majority vote within 7 days of all members being appointed. If a chairperson is not selected within 30 days, all current members will be discharged. Vacancies in the Commission will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members are entitled to receive compensation equivalent to the annual rate of basic pay for level V of the Executive Schedule. The Commission members are entitled to compensation based on the Executive Schedule. Six members constitute a quorum for decision-making, and meetings are called by the chairperson or upon request by 6 members. Vacancies in the Commission are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint necessary staff without following standard appointment procedures. Additionally, fast track procedures for recommendations are in place. The Commission must submit a report to Congress within 30 days of the 105th Congress convening, detailing the study conducted. The report may include recommendations for changes in laws governing Federal campaigns, and if 7 or more members agree on a recommendation, they must prepare a bill to implement it. Each implementing bill will be submitted with the report for Congress to consider. The Commission must submit a report to Congress within 30 days of the 105th Congress convening, detailing the study conducted. If 7 or more members agree on a recommendation for changes in Federal campaign conduct, they must prepare a bill to implement it. The implementing bill will be given expedited consideration by Congress, similar to a trade agreement bill. The Commission will cease to exist 30 days after submitting the report. $750,000 is authorized for carrying out this Act.
